bibl.title: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, August 7, 1940

div1.p: Rodriguez Leon did not find the negatives Hench requested. She offers further assistance and discusses the Cuban elections.

div1.head: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, August 7, 1940
div1.opener:
311 Calle, Sentre He ???,
Vedado, Havana, Cuba.
August 7th 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am almost ashamed to answer
your letter of April 30th at this late date,
and furthermore, I'm afraid this will reach
you much too late to be of any use. After
my hurried little note of thanks to Mrs. Hench
for the beautiful flowers she sent me, I was
unexpectedly appointed for an extensive
educational survey, as member of the Com-
mittee on Social Studies. Your letter came
after I left, and though most of my mail
was forwarded to our different addresses
in the interior, yours remained on my desk
with a pile of unimportant school & book
correspondence until my return in the
latter part of June. Even then, hungry for
family-life and the babys company, I have
practically lived out on the sand, at the
seashore, trying to relax after strenous
months of work, and even more anxiously,
II Ag to Am
to disregard entirely our recent elections (result
known in advance) which promise such dreary
years for this poor illfated island. We only
opened up our home in Vedado on the first of
this month. Please accept my excuses. I only
hope you have been able to find all the publi-
cations you wanted to use in some American
Library, and so your work has not been hin-
dered by my delay.

I did receive your copy & the original
carbon copy of my Father's letter to Dr. Hemmeter:
I believe I mentioned it in my short letter to Mrs
Hench.

Thank you very much for the Walter
Reed stamps and the photographs. I have
given Mrs. Estevez one of the prints where
she was inappeared. If you & Mrs Hench come again
to Havana soon, as we hope, I intend to
take you on a visit to her father's home
out in Country Club Park. It is one of the
loveliest in these parts & he has some very
faithful reproductions & valuable originals
of Spanish and Italian Hot- Mr Aguilera
(Mrs. Estevez' father) is probably one of the
wealthiest merchants in Cuba though
you would never think so, by the way
the whole family behaves.

I have not received the photographs
III
you were going to send me after having reprints
made. I hope they have not been caught in
the jam of our mails during elections. We
are still receiving magazines & papers very
irregularly. I am in no hurry for them
so you may take your time, as I feel
they are in safe keeping.

I happened to stop at the old
farm where the boxes and trunks and
boxes are stored, during my trip through
Pinar del Río. I managed to rummage
through all the conceivable places where
those negatives might have been kept. I
found hundreds of negatives but not the
ones we wanted. In fact there is a picture
of a man in an old-fashioned coat & derby
on the porch of what might have been
Las Animas or Hospital No. 1, whom
I am pretty sure is Dr. Carroll. Any-
way, I suspect my Mother put away
those important negatives in a safer
place. And that's the trouble. If ______ I
manage to find time before school
begins I shall go over what papers
are in the house again ...... but I
don't promise as the heat is pretty
awful these days.

Were you finally able to do anything with
the faded photographs I loaned you?

Well, since I am not being of any fur-
ther help, I shall close this belated letter.
Please don't hesitate to let me know if I
can be of any further use. We are looking
forward to seeing you and Mrs. Hench
again, sometime, with a better chance to enjoy
your company.

Please give her our regards and
with best wishes for yourself I remain
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Estela Agramonte Rodríguez León.
P. D.
I hope you can understand my “broken”
English. If I can help in any way for your
paper on Lazear, I promise to do so, promptly,
if you give me another opportunity.
Vale.
